nodes.bodyText:
To add to what @srnagar said. The analyze step is failing because of the following client libraries need to be defined in version_client.txt:
azure-schemaregistry-client
azure-schemaregistry-serde-avro
azure-schemaregistry-serde-common
The pom files need the appropriate tags and for the above libraries, within the sdk/schemaregistry they'll all be the current version. You'll also need to add the libraries to the eng/jacoco-test-coverage
The following external_dependencies need some work.
You'd added org.apache.avro:avro and tagged the bannedDependencies correctly in the pom files however the version tags for the dependencies, themselves are missing.
Similarly, org.easymock:easymock needs to get added to external_dependencies and correctly tagged within the pom files.
Last but not least, junit:junit dependencies need to be tagged but you're using version 4.12 and it would be great if, instead of declaring a one off, you could use the common 4.13-beta-3 version that's already defined.
Fixing the above issues should allow the analyze step to pass as well as the From Source runs. Note: You can run the pom_file_version_scanner.ps1 locally from a pwsh or powershell window. The line I linked to has the exact command and it takes like 5 seconds to run.

nodes.bodyText: Do you have a service swagger that can be used to generate clients using autorest?
@hmlam

Don't need to add implementation details about which Map type we are using since this may change over time. Added in some explanation on how to set the maximum map size along with the default value that will be used. Changes some HTML formatting for the maps that are maintained explanation. This file contains bidirectional Unicode text that may be interpreted or compiled differently than what appears below. To review, open the file in an editor that reveals hidden Unicode characters. Learn more about bidirectional Unicode characters Suggested change * Utilizes in-memory HashMap caching to minimize network I/O. *

* Max HashMap size can be configured when instantiating. * Two maps are maintained - * - SchemaRegistryObject cache by GUID - stores GUIDs previously seen in payloads * - SchemaRegistryObject cache by schema string - minimizes HTTP calls when sending payloads of same schema * Utilizes in-memory {@link Map} caching to minimize network I/O. Max size can be configured when instantiating by using {@link CachedSchemaRegistryClientBuilder#maxSchemaMapSize}, otherwise {@code 1000} will be used as the default. *

* Two maps are maintained. *

    *
  • SchemaRegistryObject cache by GUID - stores GUIDs previously seen in payloads.
    • *
  • SchemaRegistryObject cache by schema string - minimizes HTTP calls when sending payloads of same schema.
    • *

Generally, client builders use empty parameter constructors. Another benefit of setting scheamRegistryUrl with a method would allow for more general configurations like HttpPipeline, log options, etc, to be set once and different registries could be passed to build multiple clients.
Moved URL to .host()
Should these checks be moved into the building instead of the client constructor?
Yeah this is a redundant check, already in the builder.
Given that this is a default value does this need to be public? Should this be used in place when no value is passed for max map size?
Changed to default
Correction - has to be public.  'serde-avro' module requires that defaults be set in serializer and deserializer builder class.
*only default needs to be public.
Does this need to be public? Would a user of the library leverage this constant or is it for internal usage in the SDK?
Azure Core has a CoreUtils.isNullOrEmpty which covers these checks. Doesn't need to be used but centralizes the logic.
Is Locale.ENGLISH safe to use when this library goes public.
Use Locale.ROOT instead.

Should typeParserDictionary use a ConcurrentHashMap? I'm seeing that it gets used in a synchronized manner and ConcurrentHashMap could handle that internally. In one place I see checking if the map contains the key already and throwing if it does, this could be replaced with putIfAbsent and checking if the return is not null.
https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/util/concurrent/ConcurrentHashMap.html#putIfAbsent-K-V-

The logger APIs will use SLF4J's string formatting which is lazy compared to String.format, it uses a general {} instead of type specific formatting like %s or %d. Where possible look to update to using this instead as it will reduce CPU time on formatting strings that may not get used due to log level configuration.

  
    
  
    

  
  This file contains bidirectional Unicode text that may be interpreted or compiled differently than what appears below. To review, open the file in an editor that reveals hidden Unicode characters. Learn more about bidirectional Unicode characters


  


    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
                    logger.verbose(
          
          
            
                        String.format("Loaded parser for '%s' serialization format.", schemaType.toLowerCase(Locale.ENGLISH)));
          
          
            
                    logger.verbose(
          
          
            
                        "Loaded parser for '{}' serialization format.", schemaType.toLowerCase(Locale.ENGLISH));

Has a least recently used cache been thought about? Instead of clearing everything when we hit the limit just begin prune stale entries. Current logic will work but for hot path schemas they'll need to go make a network call when this case happens.
Overall, this doesn't need to be prioritized now as 1000 entries, by default, seems to be a lot of head space.
Yeah, don't need to clear all - we can use the LRU approach later.
Yeah I thought about this but figured it wasn't worth adding (*for now).  If an app has more than 1k entries, the app is going to have a lot more problems than just the cache getting fully cleared.

I see that typeParserDictionary generally has it's key lower cased to allow for case insensitive matching, I believe using a TreeMap should cover that case without needing to manually manage key casing on accesses. Using new TreeMap(String::equalsIgnoreCase) should produce the same effect.
https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/util/TreeMap.html#TreeMap-java.util.Comparator-
Using ConcurrentSkipListMap<>(String.CASE_INSENSITIVE_ORDER)
Need to null check the retryPolicy here and use the default. Another option is null checking when setting the retry policy.
Is this ever mutated? If there are plans to add static headers let's leave it, but otherwise we can just remove it.
Ok let's take it out for now.  We had some ideas on adding headers for internal testing, but we don't have any real use cases for clients adding their own headers to HTTP calls.

nodes.bodyText:
Do you know if it would be better to phrase the exception in the "why this happened" instead of "what happened"?
Attempted to decode with non-Avro schema object in AvroByteDecoder.
vs
object must be an Avro Schema.

I'm not sure this is completely correct, based on the Avro spec bytes will contain a leading long indicating the number of bytes in the byte[]. Based on my testing having Apache's implementation parse this is safe, though it may return ByteBuffer which could be unwrapped to byte[].

I think that is the expectation on how to handle byte-only payloads coming back from a message body.  Avro cares about the length of a byte array when working within a struct because it needs to know how long byte arrays are within the data structure so it doesn't read past the end of a byte array.  This specific case is for payloads that consist of nothing but a single byte array.  Avro can just read the entire payload into a buffer and return it to the user to manage.
I am adding a //todo to revisit this.
From what I remember DecoderFactory should be thread safe, this could be made static.

I would also conditionally check !(result instanceof String). It is possible to configure your schema with "avro.java.stringType":"String" to tell the parser to read the string type as java.lang.String instead of Apache's Utf8 CharSequence implementation.
Same comment about byte deserialization, this will need a leading long to indicate the number of bytes in the byte[].
Yup, see comments there.
Should we be checking both the object and primitive representations here? boolean and Boolean, int and Integer, etc.
This is for top level Object parameter, so they cannot be passed in as primitives.  Avro will handle if there are primitives as fields on the object.
This exception doesn't match the conditionals, unless IndexedRecord is a subclass of GenericContainer.
https://avro.apache.org/docs/1.9.2/api/java/org/apache/avro/generic/IndexedRecord.html
Should ByteBuffer fall into this category.
Yes it should.  added
This package doesn't exist, this should be com.azure.data.schemaregistry.avro right?
Yeah I missed this, there have been a lot of package changes.

If you look at this PR (https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-java/pull/10195/files#diff-f42ef09d2743baecc7f1c205f31c0351R113) it includes a plugin which can generate Java source code from given schemas, should be helpful for testing.

nodes.bodyText: Is there a specific reason we are creating a custom scheduler for deserialization?
Async implementation is using a threadpool to do sync work, hence the scheduler with the dedicated threadpool
This will be changed for GA.

Should we use Mono.empty() or Mono.just(new byte[0])? These will have two very different things happen when dealing with Reactor streams. The former will complete the stream without an onNext operation, the latter will trigger an onNext (triggering downstream map and flatMap operators) and will contain an empty byte[] as expected when Avro serializes a null.

Leaving this as is after discussion with Alan.
Thinking about this in terms of a user scenario makes it clear that returning empty byte array has a different meaning from returning null.  batch.tryAdd(null) throws.  batch.tryAdd(byte[0]) would not.  If there was an intermediate serialization step when doing batch.tryAdd(null), then the non-null contract breaks.
Agree. This should return Mono.just(new byte[0])

For these Javadocs is the but about instanceof meant to go into the overview of the method or specific to the return portion? Also, Javadocs are HTML so any newlines are scrubbed, if you need line separators you'll need to add

where newlines are (except when transitioning Javadoc sections such as param to param, return to throws, etc.

Yeah the question here is whether or not we should offer a config to skip the messages where schema was not recognized. I think we decided to punt the final decision after preview but I am leaning heavily towards throwing.
